etymologies: Old English wæfs, wæps, wæsp, of West Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin vespa; perhaps related to weave (from the weblike form of its nest)

definitions: a social winged insect that has a narrow waist and a sting. It constructs a paper nest from wood pulp and raises the larvae on a diet of insects.

notes.text: Family Vespidae, superfamily Vespoidea, order Hymenoptera: several genera, in particular Vespula and Polistes

shortDefinitions: social winged insect which has narrow waist and sting

definitions: a solitary winged insect with a narrow waist, mostly distantly related to the social wasps and including many parasitic kinds.

notes.text: Several superfamilies in the sections Aculeata (digger, mason, and potter wasps) and Parasitica (parasitic wasps and gall wasps), order Hymenoptera

shortDefinitions: solitary winged insect with narrow waist
